name: Release Plan
description: Structured checklist for coordinating feature releases from staging to production
example_output:
# Release Plan: AI PM Workspace v1.2.0

## Release Overview

| Field | Detail |
|-------|--------|
| **Release Name** | v1.2.0 - Framework Recommendations & Export |
| **Release Date** | March 3, 2026 |
| **Release Manager** | David Park (Tech Lead) |
| **Product Owner** | Dimitris Sotiriou (Product Director) |
| **Release Type** | Feature Release (Minor) |
| **Risk Level** | Medium (new LLM integration + new infrastructure dependency) |

---

## What Is Shipping

### New Features

| Feature | Description | Owner | Feature Flag |
|---------|-------------|-------|--------------|
| AI Framework Recommender | LLM-powered framework suggestions based on project context | Sarah L. | `enable_recommendations` |
| PDF Export | Export any generated framework document to PDF | Maria C. | `enable_pdf_export` |
| Markdown Export | Export framework output as .md file download | Maria C. | None (always on) |
| Framework Search | Search and filter across 45+ framework templates | James K. | None (always on) |

### Improvements

| Change | Description | Owner |
|--------|-------------|-------|
| Dashboard loading time | Reduced from 2.1s to 0.8s via lazy loading | Alex R. |
| Onboarding flow | New 4-step tooltip sequence for first-time users | Alex R. |
| Recent frameworks panel | Quick-access to last 5 used frameworks on dashboard | Alex R. |

### Bug Fixes

| Ticket | Description | Severity |
|--------|-------------|----------|
| PM-189 | Framework output truncated when context exceeds 4,000 characters | P2 |
| PM-192 | SWOT analysis template renders incorrect heading levels | P3 |
| PM-195 | Export button unresponsive after navigating back from settings | P2 |

---

## Pre-Release Checklist

### Code & Build (Due: Feb 28)
- [x] All feature branches merged to `release/1.2.0` branch
- [x] No open pull requests targeting the release branch
- [x] CI pipeline passes all stages (lint, test, build, security scan)
- [x] Dependency audit shows zero critical vulnerabilities
- [x] Bundle size increase is within budget (+120KB, limit was +200KB)

### Testing (Due: Feb 28)
- [x] All unit tests pass (847/847, 0 failures)
- [x] Integration test suite passes (62/62, 0 failures)
- [x] End-to-end regression suite passes (38/38, 0 failures)
- [x] Manual QA sign-off from Tom W. (QA Lead)
- [x] Cross-browser testing completed (Chrome 121, Firefox 124, Safari 17.3, Edge 121)
- [x] Performance benchmark: no regression beyond 5% from v1.1.0
- [ ] Load testing for recommendation engine: 100 concurrent users at P95 < 2s
- [ ] Accessibility audit for new UI components (WCAG 2.1 AA)

### Infrastructure (Due: March 1)
- [x] Redis (ElastiCache) instance provisioned in production
- [x] Redis connection pooling configured (max 20 connections)
- [ ] LLM API rate limits configured (10 req/min per user)
- [ ] Monitoring dashboards created for recommendation engine (latency, cache hit rate, error rate)
- [ ] Alerting rules configured: P95 latency > 3s, error rate > 5%, cache miss rate > 80%

### Feature Flags (Due: March 1)
- [ ] `enable_recommendations` flag created in LaunchDarkly, default OFF
- [ ] `enable_pdf_export` flag created, default OFF
- [ ] Rollout schedule configured (see Rollout Plan below)

### Documentation (Due: March 2)
- [ ] Release notes drafted and reviewed by Product
- [ ] API documentation updated for `/api/v1/recommendations` endpoint
- [ ] Help center articles written for PDF export and framework search
- [ ] Internal changelog updated for engineering team

### Communication (Due: March 2)
- [ ] Release announcement prepared for beta users (email + in-app banner)
- [ ] Support team briefed on new features and known limitations
- [ ] On-call team briefed on new infrastructure (Redis) and failure modes
- [ ] Stakeholder demo scheduled for March 3, 10:00 AM GMT

---

## Rollout Plan

### Phase 1: Internal (March 3)
- Enable `enable_recommendations` and `enable_pdf_export` for internal team (10 users)
- Monitor for 24 hours: error rates, latency, user feedback
- **Go/No-Go Decision**: March 4, 9:00 AM GMT

### Phase 2: Beta 10% (March 4)
- Ramp `enable_recommendations` to 10% of beta users
- Ramp `enable_pdf_export` to 10% of beta users
- Monitor for 48 hours
- **Success Criteria**: Error rate < 1%, P95 latency < 2s, no P1 bugs reported
- **Go/No-Go Decision**: March 6, 9:00 AM GMT

### Phase 3: Beta 50% (March 6)
- Ramp both flags to 50%
- Begin A/B test: recommendation vs. manual browse (conversion to framework generation)
- Monitor for 72 hours
- **Success Criteria**: Recommendation acceptance rate > 50%, no degradation in existing metrics
- **Go/No-Go Decision**: March 10, 9:00 AM GMT

### Phase 4: General Availability (March 10)
- Ramp both flags to 100%
- Remove `enable_pdf_export` flag (always on)
- Keep `enable_recommendations` flag as kill switch for 2 weeks
- Publish release announcement to all users

---

## Rollback Plan

### Immediate Rollback (< 5 minutes)
- Disable `enable_recommendations` flag in LaunchDarkly (kills recommendation UI and API calls)
- Disable `enable_pdf_export` flag (reverts to Markdown-only export)
- No deployment needed; feature flags provide instant rollback

### Full Rollback (< 30 minutes)
- If feature flag rollback is insufficient, deploy previous release `v1.1.0` from the tagged Docker image
- Database migrations in v1.2.0 are backward-compatible; no data migration rollback needed
- Redis cache can be flushed without impact (cache miss simply triggers LLM call)

### Rollback Triggers
- Error rate exceeds 5% for any new endpoint for more than 10 minutes
- P95 latency exceeds 5 seconds for recommendation endpoint
- Any P1 bug reported by 3+ users
- LLM API provider outage lasting more than 30 minutes

---

## Success Metrics (Measured at Day 7 and Day 30)

| Metric | Target (Day 7) | Target (Day 30) | Measurement |
|--------|----------------|------------------|-------------|
| Recommendation acceptance rate | > 40% | > 55% | Analytics: recommendation_accepted events / recommendation_shown events |
| Time to first framework generation | < 90 seconds | < 60 seconds | Analytics: project_created to framework_generated timestamp delta |
| PDF exports per user per week | > 0.5 | > 1.0 | Analytics: pdf_export events / active users |
| Framework search usage | > 30% of sessions | > 40% of sessions | Analytics: sessions with search_used event |
| Error rate (new endpoints) | < 1% | < 0.5% | Monitoring: 5xx responses / total requests |
| NPS impact | No decrease | +5 points | Quarterly NPS survey |

---

## Key Contacts

| Role | Person | Responsibility |
|------|--------|----------------|
| Release Manager | David Park | Coordinates release, makes Go/No-Go calls |
| Product Owner | Dimitris Sotiriou | Feature sign-off, release notes approval |
| QA Lead | Tom Wilson | Test sign-off, regression validation |
| On-Call Engineer | Sarah Lopez (primary), James Kim (secondary) | Incident response during rollout |
| Support Lead | Rachel Adams | User-facing communication, ticket triage |
system_prompt:
You are an experienced release manager creating a release plan for a software product.

Based on the provided context, create a detailed release plan that serves as the coordination document for shipping a new version. This document should give every stakeholder a clear picture of what is shipping, when, and what needs to happen before, during, and after the release.

## Structure:

1. **Release Overview**: Table with release name, version, date, release manager, product owner, release type (major/minor/patch/hotfix), and risk level.

2. **What Is Shipping**: Organize into three sections:
   - **New Features**: Table with feature name, description, owner, and feature flag name
   - **Improvements**: Non-feature enhancements (performance, UX, etc.)
   - **Bug Fixes**: Resolved issues with ticket IDs and severity

3. **Pre-Release Checklist**: Detailed checklist organized by category:
   - **Code & Build**: Branch status, CI pipeline, dependency audit, bundle size
   - **Testing**: Unit, integration, E2E, manual QA, cross-browser, performance, accessibility
   - **Infrastructure**: New services, database changes, configuration
   - **Feature Flags**: Flag creation, default states, rollout schedule
   - **Documentation**: Release notes, API docs, help center, internal changelog
   - **Communication**: Announcements, support briefing, on-call briefing, stakeholder demo
   Include due dates for each category.

4. **Rollout Plan**: Phased rollout with percentage ramps, duration per phase, success criteria, and Go/No-Go decision points. Typically: Internal -> 10% -> 50% -> 100%.

5. **Rollback Plan**: Two levels:
   - **Immediate Rollback**: Feature flag toggle (< 5 minutes)
   - **Full Rollback**: Previous version deployment (< 30 minutes)
   Include specific rollback triggers (error rate thresholds, latency spikes, critical bugs).

6. **Success Metrics**: Table with metric name, Day 7 target, Day 30 target, and measurement method.

7. **Key Contacts**: Table with role, person, and responsibility during the release.

## Guidelines:
- Use checkbox format for all checklist items so the team can track progress
- Be specific about dates, times, and time zones
- Include both technical and non-technical stakeholders
- Define clear, measurable Go/No-Go criteria for each rollout phase
- Rollback plan should be executable by any on-call engineer without additional context
- Success metrics should be measurable from Day 1 with existing tooling
guiding_questions: What is the release version and target date?
What features, improvements, and bug fixes are included?
What new infrastructure or dependencies are being introduced?
What is the rollout strategy (big bang, phased, canary)?
Who are the key stakeholders and their roles in the release?
What are the rollback triggers and procedures?
What metrics will you track to measure release success?
